title: Guianan warbling antbird
text:
The Guianan warbling antbird ("Hypocnemis cantator") is an insectivorous bird in the <a href="antbird">antbird</a> family, Thamnophilidae. It is found at lower levels in humid forest in the <a href="Guianas">Guianas</a>, far eastern <a href="Venezuela">Venezuela</a> (with <a href="Guyana">Guyana</a>), and north-eastern <a href="Brazil">Brazil</a> (north of the <a href="Amazon%20River">Amazon River</a> and east of the lower <a href="Rio%20Negro%20%28Amazon%29">Negro River</a> and the <a href="Branco%20River">Branco River</a>).
Taxonomy.
The French polymath <a href="Georges-Louis%20Leclerc%2C%20Comte%20de%20Buffon">Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte de Buffon</a> <a href="species%20description">described</a> the Guianan warbling antbird in his "Histoire Naturelle des Oiseaux" in 1779. The bird was also illustrated in a hand-coloured plate engraved by <a href="Fran%C3%A7ois-Nicolas%20Martinet">François-Nicolas Martinet</a> in the "Planches Enluminées D'Histoire Naturelle" which was produced under the supervision of <a href="Edme-Louis%20Daubenton">Edme-Louis Daubenton</a> to accompany Buffon's text. Buffon did not include a scientific name with his description but in 1783 the Dutch naturalist <a href="Pieter%20Boddaert">Pieter Boddaert</a> coined the <a href="binomial%20name">binomial name</a> "Formicarius cantatar" in his catalogue of the "Planches Enluminées". The <a href="specific%20name%20%28zoology%29">specific name</a> is from the Latin "cantator" "a singer". The present genus "<a href="Hypocnemis">Hypocnemis</a>" was introduced by the German ornithologist <a href="Jean%20Cabanis">Jean Cabanis</a> in 1847.
The <a href="Imeri%20warbling%20antbird">Imeri</a>, <a href="Peruvian%20warbling%20antbird">Peruvian</a>, <a href="yellow-breasted%20warbling%20antbird">yellow-breasted</a>, <a href="Rondonia%20warbling%20antbird">Rondonia</a> and <a href="Spix%27s%20warbling%20antbird">Spix's warbling antbird</a> were all formerly treated as <a href="subspecies">subspecies</a> of the Guianan warbling antbird. A study published in 2007 found that there were significant vocal differences as well a small plumage differences between the taxa and they are now all treated as separate species. As presently defined, the Guianan warbling antbird is <a href="monotypic">monotypic</a>, although the subspecies "notaea" sometimes has been recognized.
Its conservation status has been assessed as near threatened.
